required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Neurobehavioral Intervention as a Novel Treatment Approach for Emotion-Regulatory Deficits
clinical_study.official_title: Neurobehavioral Intervention as a Novel Treatment Approach for Emotion-Regulatory Deficits

brief_summary.textblock: The present study will explore the effectiveness of a computer based neurobehavioral intervention in alleviating symptoms and improving emotion regulation in psychiatric populations. It will increase understanding of psychopathology at a neural-circuit level and aid development of new non-pharmacological treatment for emotion regulatory deficits.

primary_outcome.measure: Reaction Time to Facial Affect Identification During Emotional Conflict
primary_outcome.description: A standardized set of facial emotions (fear and happy) were presented for a duration of about 1 second in quick succession (a new face every 3-5 seconds). Across each face was written an emotional word ("FEAR" or "HAPPY"), which could be either congruent or incongruent with the facial expression. The participant was instructed to identify the facial emotion as quickly as possible and ignore the overlaid emotion word. The outcome measure of interest was the average speed (across all trials presented) within which an individual could correctly identify the facial emotion as a function of time (pre or post-intervention), treatment arm (control or intervention), facial affect (fear or happy), and congruency of word and facial affect (congruent or incongruent).

primary_outcome.measure: Amygdala Blood Oxygenation-level Dependent Response (BOLD) Activation to Face Affect Identification During Emotional Conflict
primary_outcome.description: The degree of differential BOLD signal change (T2*-weighted contrast in a defined region of the brain as measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging) within each individual, averaged across trials, during facial affect identification (fear or happy) and induction of emotional conflict (when the emotion word "FEAR" or "HAPPY" was either congruent or incongruent with the facial expression). We examined the differential degree of amygdala BOLD signal change as a function of emotion type (fear or happy), congruency (congruent or incongruent), and hemisphere (left or right) at baseline and 3 months.

arm_group.description: Participants will log into a personalized website and engage in computerized tasks online.
Participants will log into a personalized website and engage in computerized tasks online.

intervention.description: Targeted, computerized interventions completed from the participants' own home on a computer.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- current anxiety or depression symptoms
- internet access
Exclusion Criteria:
- lifetime psychotic disorder, past-year substance dependence

facility.name: Stanford University, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences

group.title: Neurobehavioral Computerized Tasks
group.description: Participants will log into a personalized website and engage in computerized tasks online. Computerized Neurobehavioral Intervention: Targeted, computerized interventions completed from the participants' own home on a computer.

outcome.title: Reaction Time to Facial Affect Identification During Emotional Conflict
outcome.description: A standardized set of facial emotions (fear and happy) were presented for a duration of about 1 second in quick succession (a new face every 3-5 seconds). Across each face was written an emotional word ("FEAR" or "HAPPY"), which could be either congruent or incongruent with the facial expression. The participant was instructed to identify the facial emotion as quickly as possible and ignore the overlaid emotion word. The outcome measure of interest was the average speed (across all trials presented) within which an individual could correctly identify the facial emotion as a function of time (pre or post-intervention), treatment arm (control or intervention), facial affect (fear or happy), and congruency of word and facial affect (congruent or incongruent).
outcome.population: Participants who complete the protocol were included in the analysis.

group.title: Engaging Computerized Tasks
group.description: Participants will log into a personalized website and engage in computerized tasks online. Computerized Neurobehavioral Intervention: Targeted, computerized interventions completed from the participants' own home on a computer.

group.title: Neurobehavioral Computerized Tasks
group.description: Participants will log into a personalized website and engage in computerized tasks online. Computerized Neurobehavioral Intervention: Targeted, computerized interventions completed from the participants' own home on a computer.

measure.title: Reaction Time to Facial Affect Identification During Emotional Conflict
measure.description: A standardized set of facial emotions (fear and happy) were presented for a duration of about 1 second in quick succession (a new face every 3-5 seconds). Across each face was written an emotional word ("FEAR" or "HAPPY"), which could be either congruent or incongruent with the facial expression. The participant was instructed to identify the facial emotion as quickly as possible and ignore the overlaid emotion word. The outcome measure of interest was the average speed (across all trials presented) within which an individual could correctly identify the facial emotion as a function of time (pre or post-intervention), treatment arm (control or intervention), facial affect (fear or happy), and congruency of word and facial affect (congruent or incongruent).
measure.population: Participants who complete the protocol were included in the analysis.

analysis.groups_desc: A linear mixed model was utilized to test the null hypothesis that the intervention groups would show equivalent performance change on the outcome measure from baseline to the 3 month time points.
analysis.p_value_desc: A-priori threshold for statistical significance: p < 0.05. No correction for multiple comparisons. The omnibus effect from the linear mixed model for the Treatment Arm x Time Interaction was utilized to establish significance of the effect.
analysis.method_desc: Numerator degrees of freedom=1, Denominator degrees of freedom = 168
analysis.param_type: Type III Tests of Fixed Effects

outcome.title: Amygdala Blood Oxygenation-level Dependent Response (BOLD) Activation to Face Affect Identification During Emotional Conflict
outcome.description: The degree of differential BOLD signal change (T2*-weighted contrast in a defined region of the brain as measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging) within each individual, averaged across trials, during facial affect identification (fear or happy) and induction of emotional conflict (when the emotion word "FEAR" or "HAPPY" was either congruent or incongruent with the facial expression). We examined the differential degree of amygdala BOLD signal change as a function of emotion type (fear or happy), congruency (congruent or incongruent), and hemisphere (left or right) at baseline and 3 months.

measure.title: Amygdala Blood Oxygenation-level Dependent Response (BOLD) Activation to Face Affect Identification During Emotional Conflict
measure.description: The degree of differential BOLD signal change (T2*-weighted contrast in a defined region of the brain as measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging) within each individual, averaged across trials, during facial affect identification (fear or happy) and induction of emotional conflict (when the emotion word "FEAR" or "HAPPY" was either congruent or incongruent with the facial expression). We examined the differential degree of amygdala BOLD signal change as a function of emotion type (fear or happy), congruency (congruent or incongruent), and hemisphere (left or right) at baseline and 3 months.

analysis.groups_desc: A linear mixed model was used to test the null hypothesis that the two treatment groups would display no differential changes in amygdala BOLD signal from baseline to 3 months as a main effect or in interaction with facial affect type (fear or happy) or by brain hemisphere (left or right).
analysis.p_value_desc: No adjustment for multiple comparisons. The a priori threshold was: p < 0.05.
analysis.method_desc: Numerator degrees of freedom: 1, Denominator degrees of freedom: 168
analysis.param_type: Type III Tests of Fixed Effects

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
